repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Urban Fifth Project in Support of
            the First Phase of the Urban Development Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fifth Urban Project for Ghana had
            the following ratings: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was modest, and the Bank and borrower performance
            were both satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that
            many development tasks require more years to accomplish than
            the life of a typical investment project, and phased
            instruments are very effective to build relevant
            institutions, deal with initial capacity constrains, and
            cope with changing interests and priorities of borrowing
            countries. Linking investment funds to performance
            incentives to improve local government capacity through
            learning by doing stimulates competition and increases the
            chances of achieving long-term development effectiveness.
            Professionals with backgrounds in financial management and
            institutional development should be put in leadership
            positions at the national level in projects that promote the
            decentralization of government service provision and the
            development of local government capacity. There was
            insufficient performance monitoring and evaluation of
            Ghana's construction industry within government.
            Sub-projects should be chosen with the participation of the
            affected population and should be prioritized by the DAs in
            Medium Term Development Plans. Projects assisted by several
            donors should be coordinated at the District level.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fifth Urban Project in Ghana, is the
            first phase supporting the Urban Development Program, and it
            will ensure adequate urban infrastructure, and services, in
            particular, for the under-served secondary towns. The
            components will: 1) provide training to the District
            Assemblies' (DAs) staff in planning, and management,
            including contract management practices, development of
            maintenance management programs, and overall financial
            management, and mobilization practices. In particular, the
            DA staff will be trained to involve communities in the
            development process, and to prioritize their needs; 2)
            provide technical assistance in specific areas, to enhance
            the planning, management, and resource mobilization
            capability of DAs. This includes strengthening of financial
            management capacity through revenue improvement action
            plans, and financial management systems development.
            Following the completion of the mapping exercise, technical
            assistance will be provided for property revaluation; 3)
            finance the production of new digital, and hard copy base
            maps, and build the surveying capacity within regional
            offices; 4) finance infrastructure, and services
            subprojects, to improve the health, and environmental
            conditions of local communities; and, 5) co-finance the
            mapping component with the Nordic Development Fund, and,
            infrastructure sub-projects with the Agence Francaise de Developpement.
